channel.title: Moving out
channel.description:
I am planning on moving out within the next month to my own place. I am having troubles at home with parents and i am not really getting along with them like i used to, and it's getting to the point where all we say to each other is that we are going to kick the shit out of one another.
Does anyone have any tips on moving out or living on your own? I am 16 and have a part time job, i make around 1,635$ CAD monthly. And i work at the local boxing gym.
I am bringing a couch, a flatscreen tv, basic shit such as chairs, clothes and whatnot.
I'm asking for help, not for criticism.

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

This thread is still open? Get a clue a this forums is not a place for a question like this.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“Adam, post:24, topic:356983”]Whoever will rent an apartment to a 16 year old is a fucking moron. Contracts cannot be legally bound unless you’ve got a full time job.

Aaron, your immaturity in this thread has shown me (and others, which you’ve decided to push off) that you’re not ready to move out of your house. Take the advice of the others and fix your side of the relationship with your family. You’ll be surprised to see that changing your attitude is going to change the attitude of others around you.[/quote]

Adam, you need to read what i have also posted contrary to the apartment situation

I’m currently under care under an organization called the Ministry, basically the agreement is if i leave home they split my utilities with me, and groceries, etc. I need to pay the other half. (They are also my co-signers for my Apartment if i had an accident happen, or i owe the bank money for example, they will take over the payment for that month, usually giving me a few opportunities to set myself straight financially)

When people are pricks, i fire back. At least analyze the thread Adam, i ask for help, i didn’t ask for CRITICISM.

Most of the pre-pubescent mongoloid fucks that simply cannot post without posting something useless will receive my gunfire back.

Especially users like Errorist who keep putting gasoline on a fire.

Edit: Don’t bother making a big post about how i shouldn’t move out, i could really care less.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @Mod_Adam Adam
item.description:
@Mod_Adam wrote:

Whoever will rent an apartment to a 16 year old is a fucking moron. Contracts cannot be legally bound unless you’ve got a full time job.

Aaron, your immaturity in this thread has shown me (and others, which you’ve decided to push off) that you’re not ready to move out of your house. Take the advice of the others and fix your side of the relationship with your family. You’ll be surprised to see that changing your attitude is going to change the attitude of others around you.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“Errorist, post:21, topic:356983”][quote author=`Aaron link=topic=453506.msg3323390#msg3323390 date=1282896180]

Try spending a little less money on hats and you’ll be fine with your current income.

Good one troll, after the topic was cleaned with your stupidity and retarded comments, why not use a little bit of that “Errorist” brain power to sense when it’s time to grow up and actually put a little thought into your posts?
[/quote]Now it’s clear to me.
Your anger issues are what got you in trouble with your parents in the first place, calm down.

And really why make a thread whining about your parents and expect everyone to take your side? You had my post deleted because it wasn’t sympathetic enough for you? [/quote]

No i had the comment removed because you are obviously a spamming troll. Was i asking anyone to take my side?

I was asking for TIPS not for CRITICISM, now i know the title should have been Moving out, Trolls welcome!

I could really care less about what you think of me. You’re obviously an uneducated troll who is pretty hated upon this website, and probably IRL. Don’t attempt to send me criticism, you should take a long hard think about your pathetic life.

Stop insulting others on a forum and trying to make your e-penis bigger.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Errorist, post:21, topic:356983”][quote author=`Aaron link=topic=453506.msg3323390#msg3323390 date=1282896180]

Try spending a little less money on hats and you’ll be fine with your current income.

Good one troll, after the topic was cleaned with your stupidity and retarded comments, why not use a little bit of that “Errorist” brain power to sense when it’s time to grow up and actually put a little thought into your posts?
[/quote]Now it’s clear to me.
Your anger issues are what got you in trouble with your parents in the first place, calm down.

And really why make a thread whining about your parents and expect everyone to take your side? You had my post deleted because it wasn’t sympathetic enough for you? [/quote]
Your an idiot for thinking its always the ‘child’s’ fault. Some people, the parents can be the problem. I was in an abusive setting for around 7-8 years. Here was the issue that would bring up some of the abusive settings: Mowing the yard (mind you the state i lived in at the time, was in the triple didgets for temperature [112F i believe?]), After it was about half done, i decided to come inside for a drink, and to sit for 2-3 minutes. Simple right? No, not for my step-dad, it had to be done right there and then, or i wasn’t doing it at all to him. He went out to finish it (after beating me around), and ended up having a heat-stroke. Shows that bastard right. My hate twards him wrong? No, not to me.

Read full topic

Groceries aren’t a problem. You can get all your groceries for less than $10 each month if you know what to do.

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:16, topic:356983”][quote author=`Aaron link=topic=453506.msg3322835#msg3322835 date=1282852803]
You don’t think $400 is enough for groceries?
[/quote]

Grocery Coupon Guide – 30 Apr 10

Eating Well On $1 A Day - Grocery Coupon Guide

Coupons powered by Coupons.com Note: If this is your first time to this challenge, you may want to read over the frequently asked questions. You may also be interested in how I did it without spending a whole lot of time by incorporating lazy...

I would say buying water/gas/electricity will be the hardest thing to so dedicate a lot of time to finding the best deal and even use those price comparison sites.[/quote]

Much appreciated. I really don’t care about food brands either, so i won’t mind not buying the name brand peanut butter, or other things.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

`Aaron:

You don’t think $400 is enough for groceries?

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“T3arful, post:12, topic:356983”]How do you expect to live on 1,635$ a month? Rent and various other bills are going to swallow that up, what are you going to do for food? Live on cheap noodles or something? You’re going to attempt to juggle a job and an education at 16, you’re going to end up giving up your education and inevitably going to be stuck at a dead end job.

Bite your lip and put up with the shit from your parents. You won’t be capable of living by your own means yet, and if it goes tits up you’re only going to end up back at home anyway.[/quote]

You don’t think $400 is enough for groceries?

@Coon, i lived in an abusive household for 8 years, physical and emotional abuse, after continual years of abuse i decided to live with a grandparent. Out of nowhere she had a psychotic episode and hasn’t stopped screaming since, so i feel that i need to be on my own, i also have some support from my brother, so that’ll help also. He’s my employer too.

Read full topic

item.description:

You can easily live on $1,600 bucks a month. Stay with your parents as long as you can.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j

@doom_j wrote:

You will need to get a low income housing unit with utility’s included.

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

How do you expect to live on 1,635$ a month? Rent and various other bills are going to swallow that up, what are you going to do for food? Live on cheap noodles or something? You’re going to attempt to juggle a job and an education at 16, you’re going to end up giving up your education and inevitably going to be stuck at a dead end job.

Bite your lip and put up with the shit from your parents. You won’t be capable of living by your own means yet, and if it goes tits up you’re only going to end up back at home anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:8, topic:356983”][quote author=ziplock link=topic=453506.msg3322413#msg3322413 date=1282825216]
Not all parents are loving, too bad that people can’t possibly believe that.
[/quote]
My Step-Dad as an example. He used to wake me up by kicking me, would push me into the air via my neck, plenty of odd shit that my mother never knew about.

@TOPIC - As sugested, make a budget sheet of what you will need, and figure out what extra you will have, or if you wont have enough. Its not a good idea to just go out on your own without knowing the cost of things, so make sure you shop around. I know around me there are apartments for $500 (USD), but idk if that would be the case in Canada. Try to stick it out for another month, and see about getting prepared.[/quote]

I’m looking one near me at around $900, the utilities aren’t included though. I already have a budget sheet that I’m working on right now.

[quote=“Errorist, post:2, topic:357007”]Aaron, Miss Silbasoft was giving you the best advice possible, no need to start name calling.

Maybe this is how you are with your loving parents? They guide you in life and you insult them? [/quote]

There is no name calling, i was telling the truth.

Maybe you should ask what goes on in my house, rather than just assume.

Read full topic

sounds like you dont realize how big of an undertaking it is

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I’d agree with Coon about sticking it out for a bit longer. I’d look into getting a better job first of all. It’ll be very hard to live on less than 2k a month.

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Not all parents are loving, too bad that people can’t possibly believe that.

My Step-Dad as an example. He used to wake me up by kicking me, would push me into the air via my neck, plenty of odd shit that my mother never knew about.

@TOPIC - As sugested, make a budget sheet of what you will need, and figure out what extra you will have, or if you wont have enough. Its not a good idea to just go out on your own without knowing the cost of things, so make sure you shop around. I know around me there are apartments for $500 (USD), but idk if that would be the case in Canada. Try to stick it out for another month, and see about getting prepared.

Read full topic

@Nocternal wrote:

Yeah just remember to have enough for rent and food at like all time’s, and other necessity’s.

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

[quote=“Errorist, post:2, topic:357007”]Aaron, Miss Silbasoft was giving you the best advice possible, no need to start name calling.

Maybe this is how you are with your loving parents? They guide you in life and you insult them? [/quote]

We don’t know everything that goes on with his parents. So it’s best we stay away from that topic.

That’s plenty enough to live on your own. Always remember your other needs too though, like food, clothes, etc… Just try to handle being with your parent for a little while longer and save as much as you can. That way you won’t be stressed the first few months about bills. I know some apartment complexes offer free water and cable. So be looking for that. Good luck…

Read full topic

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:2, topic:356983”]I doubt you could get a apartment at 16, you will most likely need your parents as co signers.

Get your birth certificate, a criminal report, a credit check.

By the looks of your income I suggest a low in come housing unit or even a studio. But you may also have to apply for medicare, if you have a illness like depression, or other psychological health problems.

EDIT: I also suggest you create a budge sheet to see what you can afford before you go out buying or renting[/quote]

I am under care under a foster agency, they have agreed to sign for me if i agree to continue to go to school and work. I am also from Canada so i get free health care.

[quote=“Primadude, post:1, topic:357007”]Too bad you’ll spend that money on drugs and shitty hats.

Lol jk, make up with your parents; it’ll save a lot of hassle.[/quote]

I live with one parent who has psychotic episodes.

Miss Silabsoft:

I suggest its time to grow up and stop being such a douche to your parents, Judging by the info you have provided.

Sorry Silabsoft, but i don’t see where your input is needed? I’m asking for tips on moving out, not asking for smart remarks from a troll that somehow got GM.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Moving out
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

I doubt you could get a apartment at 16, you will most likely need your parents as co signers.

Get your birth certificate, a criminal report, a credit check.

By the looks of your income I suggest a low in come housing unit or even a studio. But you may also have to apply for medicare, if you have a illness like depression, or other psychological health problems.

EDIT: I also suggest you create a budge sheet to see what you can afford before you go out buying or renting

Read full topic
